sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small (about 2-3 feet tall)

entries.name: Ashen Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell Minor Illusion|XPHB} cantrip. Additionally, starting at character level 3 you always have the {@spell Charm Person|XPHB} spell prepared, and starting at character level 5 you always have the {@spell Invisibility|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast them each once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast them in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast them using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Fiendish Fortune
entries: When you're hit by an attack roll that isn't a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB}, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to magically cause the attack to miss you, and a creature of your choice within 5 feet of you takes Force damage equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Scorpion Sting
entries: You have a tail stinger you can use to make {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes} using your Strength or Dexterity (your choice) for attack and damage rolls. On a hit, you deal {@damage 1d4} Piercing damage, and you can deal an extra {@damage 1d6} Poison damage. You can deal this extra damage a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. You regain one expended use when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
When you reach character level 10, this extra damage increases to {@dice 2d6}.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Fiend.

entries.name: Ashen Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell Minor Illusion} cantrip. Starting at 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Charm Person} spell using this trait, and starting at 5th level, you can cast the {@spell Invisibility} spell using this trait, both without requiring material components. Once you cast {@spell Charm Person} or {@spell Invisibility} with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a long rest. You can also cast either of those spells using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense darkvision} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Fiendish Fortune
entries: When you're hit by an attack roll that isn't a critical hit, you can use your reaction to magically cause the attack to miss you, and a creature of your choice within 5 feet of you takes force damage equal to your proficiency bonus. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Scorpion Sting
entries: You have a tail stinger you can use to make unarmed strikes using your Strength or Dexterity (your choice) for attack and damage rolls. On a hit, you deal {@damage 1d4} piercing damage, and you can deal an extra {@damage 1d6} poison damage. You can deal this extra damage a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain one expended use when you finish a short rest, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
When you reach 10th level, this extra damage increases to {@dice 2d6}.

entries.name: Azure Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell Guidance|XPHB} cantrip. Starting at character level 3, you always have the {@spell Augury|XPHB} spell prepared and can cast it once without a spell slot or Material components, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Glimpse Fate
entries: When you roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}, if you aren't {@status surprised|XPHB}, you can choose a number of creatures that you can see equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. The targets have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on their {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} rolls. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Winds of Magic
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can take the {@action Dash|XPHB} action and increase your {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} by 10 feet until the end of the turn. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Azure Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell Guidance} cantrip. Starting at 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Augury} spell with this trait without requiring a material component. Once you cast {@spell Augury} with this trait, you can't cast it in that way again until you finish a long rest. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Darkvision

entries.name: Glimpse Fate
entries: When you roll initiative, if you aren't {@status surprised}, you can choose a number of creatures that you can see equal to your proficiency bonus. The targets have advantage on their initiative rolls. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Winds of Magic
entries: As a bonus action, you can take the {@action Dash} action and increase your flying speed by 10 feet until the end of the turn. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries: Medium (about 7-8 feet tall)

entries.name: Bog Bulk
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on any ability check you make to end the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition.
You also count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Guiding Bond
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can magically place a mark on a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself.

The mark lasts for 1 minute, and takes the form of ephemeral plants, moss, fungus, or swamp animals that only you can see. For the duration, you can add {@dice 1d4} to ability checks and attack rolls you make against the marked creature. You can use this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Perception|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Regeneration
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can expend one of your {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB}, roll the die, and regain a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the number rolled plus your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point}).
If you take Acid or Fire damage, this trait doesn't function until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Cursed Claws
entries: You have claws you can use to make {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes}, which deal {@damage 1d6} Slashing damage on a hit. You can use Strength or Dexterity for attack and damage rolls with your claws.

When you hit a creature with your claws, you can curse the target until the start of your next turn. While cursed, the target emits wisps of fog and has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests}. You can curse a creature a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Grey Balance
entries: When you fail a saving throw, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to succeed instead. When you do, you have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} until the end of your next turn. You can use this trait once, and you regain the ability to do so when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Lupine Sense
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Investigation|XPHB}, {@skill Perception|XPHB}, or {@skill Survival|XPHB} skill.

When you hit a creature with your claws, you can curse the target until the start of your next turn. While cursed, the target emits wisps of fog and has disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws. You can curse a creature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Eldritch Gibbering
entries: Thanks to your eldritch connection to the Hungering Ones, you speak {@language Deep Speech|XPHB}. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can gibber in that language. Each creature of your choice in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 plus your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} and Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma modifier; choose the ability when you select this species) or roll a {@dice d6} and consult the table below. The effect lasts until the start of your next turn. Once any target fails its save against this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

rows: The target has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls.
The target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} becomes 0.
The target can't take {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions}.

entries.name: Endless Hunger
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can embrace your connection to the Hungering Ones. Until the start of your next turn, you know the location of any creatures that aren't Constructs or Undead within 60 feet of yourself, and your attack rolls against those creatures can't have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Deep Roots
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on ability checks and saving throws against being moved against your will or to avoid the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Elderwood Whispers
entries: You can draw on the memory of the Elderwood spirits. When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you gain proficiency with a skill, a tool, or learn one language of your choice until you next finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Grasping Branches
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can magically unleash the binding power of the dark wood. Choose a Large or smaller creature within 30 feet of yourself. The creature must make a Strength saving throw (DC 8 plus your Constitution modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}). On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition for 1 minute as branches appear and ensnare it. On a successful save, its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is halved until the end of its next turn. A {@condition Restrained|XPHB} creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. The branches vanish when the condition ends.
Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Root Sense
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you gain {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet for 10 minutes. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Devour Corpse
entries: You can eat spoiled and rotten food as if it were fresh.

Additionally, if you spend 1 minute eating flesh from the corpse of a Small or larger creature that isn't a Construct, roll one of your {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB} without expending it (even if you have none remaining). You regain a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the number rolled plus your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point}). Once you regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} using this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Starting at character level 3, you always have the {@spell Find Familiar|XPHB} spell (the familiar takes the form of a jeweled insect or arachnid) prepared, and starting at character level 5, you always have the {@spell Web|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast each spell once without a spell slot or Material components. You regain the ability to cast them in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast either spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Spider Climb
entries: You can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing an ability check and while leaving your hands free.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your walking speed is 30 feet, and you have a climbing speed equal to your walking speed.

entries.name: Bejeweled Carapace
entries: When you are hit with an attack roll, you can use your reaction to add your proficiency bonus to your AC against that attack, potentially causing it to miss. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Silken Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell Thaumaturgy} cantrip. Starting at 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Find Familiar} spell (the familiar takes the form of a jeweled insect or arachnid) using this trait, and starting at 5th level, you can cast the {@spell Web}  spell using this trait, both without material components. Once you cast {@spell Find Familiar} or Web  with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a long rest. You can also cast either spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Spider Climb
entries: You can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing an ability check and while leaving your hands free.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-7 feet tall) or Small (about 3-4 feet tall), chosen when you select this species

speedEntry.name: Speed:
entries: 30 feet, {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} equal to half your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}

entries.name: Argent Gleam
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can channel a mote of the Silver Path's light with your choice of one of the following options:

items.name: Path's Grace
entries: You cast the {@spell Bless|XPHB} spell, requiring no Material components.

items.name: Zealous Charge
entries: You take the {@action Dash|XPHB} action. The first time you make an attack roll before the end of your turn, on a hit or miss, the target takes an extra {@damage 2d6} Radiant damage.
Once you use this trait's {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Silver Bulwark
entries: You can call upon the Silver Path to protect you. When you take Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to those three damage types until the start of your next turn. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Watchful Senses
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Insight|XPHB}, {@skill Perception|XPHB}, or {@skill Survival|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Construct.

entries.name: Ball-Jointed
entries: You can move through a space as narrow as 1 foot wide as if it were {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

entries.name: Innocent Mind
entries: You have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Psychic damage.

entries.name: Sewn Nature
entries: You don't require air, food, or drink.

entries.name: Soothing Heart
entries: You know the {@spell Guidance|XPHB} cantrip. Starting at character level 3, you always have the {@spell Sanctuary|XPHB} spell prepared, and starting at character level 5, you always have the {@spell Calm Emotions|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast each spell once without a spell slot. When you cast {@spell Calm Emotions|XPHB} in this way, it can target creatures of any type. You regain the ability to cast them using this trait when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast either spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: You've Got a Friend
entries: When a creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself fails an ability check using a skill, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to cast {@spell Guidance|XPHB} on the creature, ignoring the spell's normal range. The creature can add the spell's {@dice 1d4} to its ability check, potentially causing it to succeed, then the spell ends. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Construct.

entries.name: Size
entries: You are Medium or Small. You choose the size when you select this species.

entries: You know the {@spell Guidance} cantrip. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: You've Got a Friend
entries: When a creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself fails an ability check using a skill, you can use your reaction to cast {@spell Guidance} on the creature, ignoring the spell's normal range. The creature can add the spell's {@dice 1d4} to its ability check, potentially causing it to succeed. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

raceFluff.name: Ashborn
entries: Ashborn are an imp-like species native to {@book Chernabos|CrookedMoon|1|Chernabos}, typically coalescing from the sulfuric ash of the province's hellfire and brimstone volcanoes. Infused with the fiendish power of the Hells, this folk has managed to survive and even prosper in the barrens and badlands of the province through guile, boldness, and industriousness. Said to be favored by fortune itself, ashborn count on luck to twist the balance in the most dire of situations.

Their short stature ranges from slight to stout, but this makes them no less dangerous, for each ashborn has a venomous tail resembling a scorpion's, always ready to strike. They sport horns and skin tones in varying shades of red and gray that reflect their devilish origin, and they typically live 100 years.

raceFluff.name: Azureborn
entries: Azureborn ({@i A‑zher‑born}) are a harpy-like species native to {@book Astramar|CrookedMoon|1|Astramar}, often materializing from  the bright blue night sky filled with twinkling stars  and winds of arcane power. Bearing a connection to  the aither that courses through the air and land of the province, they are an inherently prescient folk that can divine the future by looking to the cosmos. They have built a society of magical wonder through grand vision, endless curiosity, and dedication to study.

Sprouting feathers across their entire body and wings attached to each of their arms, this diverse folk can resemble all manner of avian creatures, from raptors with earthy tones to tropical birds of vibrant and colorful plumage. They typically live 100 years, although many of the wisest among them have lived up to 400.

raceFluff.name: Bogborn
entries: Bogborn are a troll-like species native to {@book Zulrogg|CrookedMoon|1|Zulrogg}, usually rising from the still, dark waters of the swampy province. From the moment of rebirth, they have a symbiotic relationship with flora and fauna of the wild—and often treacherous—mire. Their ability to survive is further enhanced by the naturally regenerative biology often found in trolls.

Towering over most, these hearty folk can face any trial of nature, and they often utilize their athleticism in pursuits of hunting and survival. Bearing prominent noses and tusks, their tough hides are generally shades of green or blue. Bogborn typically live 100 years before moving on to the spirit world.

raceFluff.name: Curseborn
entries: Curseborn are a werewolf-like species native to {@book Edwardia|CrookedMoon|1|Edwardia}, often emerging from the dense, cursed fog that rolls across the province. Sharing a strong connection to a malediction called the Grey, which demands balance at the threat of certain doom, they have managed to build a civilization of advancement and progress, countered by rampant strife, pollution, and hunger.

Covered head to toe with thick fur and bearing sharp teeth and claws, this lupine species evokes the hallmarks and appearance of wolves but with clearly humanoid physiology. If not brought to an early grave by the Grey, they typically live for up to 100 years, although technological advancement has led to certain individuals approaching 200 years old.

raceFluff.name: Deepborn
entries: Deepborn are a fish-like species native to {@book Olmarsh|CrookedMoon|1|Olmarsh}, typically rising up from the abyssal depths of the province's black seahome to terrors beyond imagining known as the Hungry Ones. Immersed in a near constant eldritch presence that emerges from the deep and descends from beyond the stars, these folk manage their state of paranoia by embracing and harnessing the uncanny and cosmic.

While they are primarily piscine in their anatomy, they can possess features found in a wide variety of sea creatures, including cephalopods and crustaceans. They typically live for around 150 years, but certain members of occult orders have been known to live for 600 years.

raceFluff.name: Gnarlborn
entries: Gnarlborn ({@i NAR-ull-born}) are a tree-like species native to {@book Ardengloom|CrookedMoon|1|Ardengloom}, usually sprouting up from the soil of the twisted, dark forest. Their home is forever haunted by the souls of long-dead Fey, which inhabit the enormous, face-bearing trees known as Elderwoods. These folk commune with these beings to receive primordial wisdom.

Resembling gnarled trees with glowing faces hollowed into the bark, their individual patterns of branches, moss, and lichen can result in a wide diversity of appearances. Most gnarlborn live for over 500 years, but those with the strongest connection to the Elderwoods have been said to live to be thousands of years old.

raceFluff.name: Graveborn
entries: Graveborn are a ghoul-like species native to {@book Syndramas|CrookedMoon|1|Syndramas}, typically rising from one of the countless graves that mark the frozen battlefields of the province. They were first created in a kingdom-wide ritual that twisted countless humans into new Undead creatures that barely resembled who they once were. Graveborn now wage war endlessly and perpetuate a culture of martial prowess, relentlessness, and grave honor. These people are infused with the necrotic and draconic essence of the powerful Drakkonite metal found throughout the province, which has given them a strange taste for spoiled flesh of any variety.

Appearing as the corpses of twisted Humanoids, graveborn have powerful snouts and jaws with elongated teeth and tongues that assist in the devouring of flesh and bone. Their physiology is sturdy, as if magically designed to be perfected for war. If not killed in war, as befalls many of their kind, they can live up to 300 years before decaying away.

raceFluff.name: Harvestborn
entries: Harvestborn are a scarecrow-like species native to {@book Enoch|CrookedMoon|1|Enoch}, most often crafted with great care by Methuselah, the lord of the province. Infused with the vital, green magic that surges through the immensely fertile land, they have a strong connection to the cycle of both the harvest and life, death, and rebirth. They feed much of Druskenvald with the crops they grow in a relatively peaceful society that puts a focus on community, family, and fellowship.

As a constructed species resembling any manner of scarecrow, their bodies are comprised of a mixture of wood, metal, straw, and other implements. Their glowing-eyed heads might be made from a burlap sack or a crop such as a pumpkin or turnip. Staying true to the cycle, they generally live 100 years before accepting the next step of death and becoming reborn once more.

raceFluff.name: Plagueborn
entries: Plagueborn are a rat-like species native to {@book Bubonia|CrookedMoon|1|Bubonia}, typically coalescing in the pestilent haze that hangs over the province. They are deeply connected to the virulent and deadly plague that afflicts and shapes their society, which persists through cunning, ruthlessness, and the sheer will to live. They are the most adaptable species of Druskenvald, quickly discovering the means to survive even the harshest environments.

Appearing as large plague rats with humanoid physiology, their short fur ranges from grays and browns to various shades of green. They bear jagged teeth and claws that all carry a strain of plague to which they are immune but can prove deadly to others. Their nimble tails can vary greatly in length and thickness, often reflecting their family, clan, or guild. Plagueborn usually live no longer than 100 years.

raceFluff.name: Relicborn
entries: Relicborn are a skeleton-like species native to {@book Kalero|CrookedMoon|1|Kalero}, generally emerging from the numerous tombs and crypts that line the canyon walls of the province. They thrive in a culture of celebration and remembrance, which infuses the very essence of every member of the species. Dancing between the energy of a vivacious party and the serenity of peaceful reflection, this folk holds a deep appreciation for both the living and the dead.

They appear as skeletons decorated with a wide array of vibrant colors, patterns, and styles, and their bones are encased in a translucent, glowing substance that provides them with a similar mass and shape to other Humanoid species, allowing them to comfortably wear clothing and armor. Some relicborn can even grow hair from their skulls, which is often shaped into bombastic styles.
Relicborn typically live for 250 years before losing their form and collapsing into a pile of bones.

raceFluff.name: Silkborn
entries: Silkborn are a spider-like species native to {@book Nerukhet|CrookedMoon|1|Nerukhet}, typically emerging from silken cocoons amidst thick webbing that fills miles of tunnels throughout the subterranean province. They have a deep kinship and connection with the bejeweled arachnids and insects that have assisted them in building the grandest civilization in Druskenvald. This folk also channels the great gems that fill the caverns of the province with light and power, bringing them ever closer to the gods that spared their kind from an ancient calamity.

While this species has humanoid proportions, they have arachnid features—hardened carapace skin, numerous eyes, segmented limbs that grow from their backs, and mandibles that sprout from their mouths. They generally live for 250 years, but those at the higher echelons of their civilizations have been known to live nearly 800 years.

raceFluff.name: Stoneborn
entries: Stoneborn are a gargoyle-like species native to {@book Pholsense|CrookedMoon|1|Pholsense}, usually meticulously carved by the lord of the province, Archbishop Danton Alexandre Renault. Blessed by the divine power known as the Silver Path, these people can call upon the godliness that suffuses their construction. In a domain of darkness, they have looked to the light of their god to build a civilization that attempts to uphold what is good and lawful at all costs.

Their stony skin matches the same hue and pattern as the stone they were carved from. While all of their kind have broad wings that carry their dense, heavy bodies, their biology can evoke a wide variety of creatures—including bats, fiends, dragons, birds, angels, dogs, and lizards—often combining features into a chimeric blend. They usually live for 300 years before crumbling into rubble.

raceFluff.name: Threadborn
entries: Threadborn are a doll-like species native to {@book Picco|CrookedMoon|1|Picco}, most often built with love by Blinski II, the master toymaker and lord of the province. In a land that is mostly fabricated and constructed to maximize the fun of all who live there, the essence of joy, thrill, and friendship are woven into a threadborn's very nature. They cherish the bonds made between loved ones and always maintain a childlike wonder and whimsy, no matter one's age.

As living dolls, these folk are constructed with a variety of materials, including cloth, wood, metal, porcelain, stuffing, yarn, and anything else a toy might be made of. With the most varied body shapes of all Druskenvald's species, each threadborn represents a unique representation of fun. They usually live for 100 years before falling apart and needing to be rebuilt.

backgroundFluff.name: Amnesiac
entries: Some portion of your past has been swallowed by nothingness. The missing time could be a short interval—mere days or weeks gone from your memory—or you might have only vague hints at best of who you are and where you are from. Flashes of dj vu are common, taunting you with recollection, but they almost always slip away, as ungraspable as the mists of Druskenvald. An injury, some traumatic experience, or the magical workings of a spell or curse could be the culprit behind your amnesia.

entries.name: Scattered Memories
entries: You don't choose skill proficiencies or a tool proficiency when you select this background, and you don't determine the two languages that are part of your origin—these are parts of your past that you are missing. Instead, you can pick one of those proficiencies or the languages during play at any time. The knowledge might return in a spontaneous flash, even as you make a roll that relies on the proficiency, or slowly emerge as you struggle to solve a problem. Once you choose one of these features, you can't choose another one until you gain a level.

The GM might rule that you can choose a new recalled feature early if something reminds you of your past, such as finding a piece of evidence from your missing memories or experiencing an event similar to one you have forgotten. Of particular value is an event relating to one of the story threads or trinkets presented below.

entries.name: Building an Amnesiac
entries: Any character can face misfortune or a choice that steals their memory. Consider how your character came to lose their memory. Was it lost through injury or illness, or did something more sinister steal it with a toxin or curse? You might decide to leave this choice up to the GM, letting you as a player discover the cause alongside your character.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: This background presents a paradox when considering threads to weave through a campaign, since the character may not remember them. Work with the GM to create some leading events or people that can serve as constants to trace a path through the void of the character's past, especially if the GM can insert existing nonplayer characters into the thread to strengthen these connections. The Amnesiac Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of these threads.

entries.caption: Amnesiac Story Threads
rows: You have recurring dreams of someone you might recognize on your adventures.
You absent-mindedly doodle the same design or symbol over and over.
A friend has been traveling the provinces of Druskenvald with a caravan, searching for any hint of your past as they do.
A rhyme or song you've never heard before comes to mind when your thoughts wander.
Rainbow colors, such as those on a soap bubble or oil slick, fill you with unexplained terror.
You have a fragmented recollection of traveling to a remote place in the mountains.

entries.name: Amnesiac Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Amnesiac Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Amnesiac Trinkets
rows: Half of a tarnished silver ring with a partial inscription in a language you don't understand
A music box that plays a sad tune you recognize but can't identify
A short note addressed to you signed with a name you don't recognize
A thin silk scarf with a fading scent that stirs familiarity
A toy horse with unfamiliar initials inked on it
A locket whose portrait is burnt and unrecognizable

backgroundFluff.name: Crimson Aspirant
entries: You have delved into the forces that animate all life—even those that counterfeit life, such as Constructs and Undead. Many of these studies concentrate on the nature of blood and its power to sustain life and transmit vital essence, binding the soul to the flesh. You might have apprenticed under a sly-hearted mentor or a secret cabal focused on understanding or even manipulating life and death. You may have learned from a detailed treatise that you've put into practice, daring to become versed in the forbidden arts.

entries.name: Building a Crimson Aspirant
entries: Characters who value study and learning, as well as those with a capacity to heal the injuries and illnesses of others, readily become crimson aspirants. More physically inclined characters can be drawn to the teachings of blood to tap into their increased vital energies, as can those who are sickly or weak in hopes of overcoming that adversity.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Crimson Aspirant Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Crimson Aspirant Story Threads
rows: Sometimes when you bleed, you hear whispers from your fallen blood that tease with meaning.
You were trained by a remote monastery, but your mentor ushered you out one morning in a panic and sent you away.
A plague carried in the blood defies cures, and you must find its origin.
Your mentor, who inducted you into the secrets held within life and blood, vanished suddenly.
Your studies reveal a spate of anemia cases, some ending in death, as the predations of blood-drinking monsters.
A loved one, such as a paramour or sibling, has died, and your studies hint at a way to bring them back.

entries.name: Crimson Aspirant Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Crimson Aspirant Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Crimson Aspirant Trinkets
rows: A glass pendant with a single drop of blood suspended within
A long scroll with an anatomical study and description of how life energy flows through the body
A handkerchief with a blood drop pressed into the center
A polished bloodstone for balancing vital energy
A vial of blood that never coagulates or dries
A small box of ashes said to be from a martyr who was falsely accused of vampirism and burned at the stake

backgroundFluff.name: Crossroads Gambler
entries: You've made your bones on games of chance, and one day your games crossed the line into something far more serious. You might have played for your soul against a Fiend, matched wits with ancient forest Fey in a riddle contest, or rolled dice with the fabled Mister Crossroads.

entries.name: Building a Crossroads Gambler
entries: Characters who live by their wits, such as Rogues and Bards, find the call of a crossroads gambler appealing, though anyone could find themselves in the position of playing for stakes higher than they could ever imagine.. or pay. A spellcaster who conjured the wrong entity may find themself a gambler. The desperate who sought out a mysterious figure to throw dice and match wits for power or salvation can find their fates bound to the crossroads.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Crossroads Gambler Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Crossroads Gambler Story Threads
rows: Someone you thought was a friend tricked you into making your bargain.
You've found that if you go too long without making a wager, your luck starts to turn sour.
You only feel alive in the midst of a contest.
You lost your bet, and you're on the run from the thing surely coming to collect.
Someone close to you made a wager and lost. You made your deal to try and find them.
You've been gambling for a long time, and you're tired. Now all you want is a way out.

entries.name: Crossroads Gambler Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Crossroads Gambler Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Crossroads Gambler Trinkets
rows: A lucky coin made of a strange material, such as green steel or bone
A battered, blood-stained six of hearts playing card
A torn journal page of a long-missing gambler who was hopeful to win their fortune from a being they describe but fail to name
The preserved foot of a rabbit, owl, or weasel
A six-sided die that somehow seems to have too many 2s when closely examined
A silver-plated ivory chess rook

backgroundFluff.name: Cultist
entries: You have been inducted into a secret society that venerates or pursues power from some otherworldly source. The cultists might serve as minions of an entity they worship, or they may seek to understand and claim its might for their own. Depending on the malevolence of the cult's patron or the malefic purposes they may serve, cultists could be a force of wickedness or a group of closely bonded and dedicated people who pursue a common, if esoteric, goal.

entries.caption: Cultist Affinities
rows: Aberration
{@skill Perception|XPHB}
Deep Speech
Celestial
{@skill Religion|XPHB}
Celestial
Fiend (Demon)
{@skill Religion|XPHB}
Abyssal
Fiend (Devil)
{@skill Religion|XPHB}
Infernal
Fey
{@skill Nature|XPHB}
Sylvan

entries.name: Cult Veneration
entries: Cults propitiate beings of otherworldly power in hopes of sharing in that potency. Choose what type of cult you joined, such as the following.

entries.name: Aberration
entries: Alien creatures with inscrutable mindsets and motivations. Many originate from outside the known multiverse.

entries.name: Celestial
entries: Beings of the Upper Planes, and paragons of order or benevolence. Many can be overbearing and uncompromising.

entries.name: Fiend (Demon)
entries: Creatures of utter evil and destruction that want to see all worlds and planes burn.

entries.name: Fiend (Devil)
entries: Beings of cunning wickedness who prize structure and obedience. They seek to subjugate others and condemn souls.

entries.name: Fey
entries: Capricious beings often associated with nature and emotional extremes. They can be beautiful, terrible, intoxicating, and horrific.

entries.name: Building a Cultist
entries: Cultists are often lost souls—individuals severed from the fabric of society whose cult became a manipulative, surrogate family. Consider if your character agrees with the aims of the cult, if they fled the group, or if they remain for infiltration purposes.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Cultist Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Cultist Story Threads
rows: You learned that the cult that took you in manipulated you throughout your life.
A member of your cult betrayed and killed your leader and mentor.
Your cult's activities aroused the ire and superstition of locals, deserved or not.
You followed a loved one into joining the cult, trying to find out what happened to them.
You met someone who forced you to see the cult you always venerated in a different light.
You joined the cult to save yourself from an incurable illness or other certain doom.

entries.name: Cultist Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Cultist Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Cultist Trinkets
rows: A sealed scroll of esoteric knowledge
A steel ball bearing etched over its entire surface with your cult's sacred text
A crystal that feels strange to the touch
A ritual knife stained with blood, sap, or oils
A set of copper tattoo needles
An embroidered cloth half mask

Your cult's activities aroused the ire and superstition of locals, deserved or not.
You followed a loved one into joining the cult, trying to find out what happened to them.
You met someone who forced you to see the cult you always venerated in a different light.
You joined the cult to save yourself from an incurable illness or other certain doom.

entries.name: Cultist Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Cultist Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Cultist Trinkets
rows: A sealed scroll of esoteric knowledge
A steel ball bearing etched over its entire surface with your cult's sacred text
A crystal that feels strange to the touch
A ritual knife stained with blood, sap, or oils
A set of copper tattoo needles
An embroidered cloth half mask

backgroundFluff.name: Druskenvald Dweller
entries: You hail from one of the thirteen baneful provinces of Druskenvald. You might be a member of the unique species known to originate from those diverse biomes, or you may be of a different heritage altogether. The skills and culture of your home (summarized below) shape your knowledge and early experiences.

entries.name: Building a Druskenvald Dweller
entries: Any sort of character can be a Druskenvald dweller. When you make your character, decide if you belong to the species associated with your home province, or if you are of another kind who was raised outside the home of most of your species. This decision itself may determine truths about your character to be experienced throughout your journeys in Druskenvald.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Druskenvald Dweller Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Druskenvald Dweller Story Threads
rows: You were left on a church doorstep as an infant. The only clue to your origin is the torn cloak used as a blanket.
You fled your home province after being accused of a crime, whether justly or not.
After hearing stories of other provinces, you struck out to see more of Druskenvald.
Members of a trade caravan stole something or harmed someone dear to you.
You made a desperate pact with an ashborn and now seek to nullify the contract.
A vicious bogborn bounty hunter trails you.

entries.name: Druskenvald Dweller Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Druskenvald Dweller Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Druskenvald Dweller Trinkets
rows: A brass needle with a dangling bit of broken thread
A dull, rusty sickle with a bone handle
A star chart etched onto a crystal plate
A wicker doll with bloodstained bead eyes
A length of chain that sometimes rattles when left unattended
A mummified hand preserved in bog peat

backgroundFluff.name: Experiment
entries: You are forever altered in some drastic, physical way, perhaps even made monstrous. A blasphemous fusion of science, alchemy, and magic changed you, possibly to mend some unrecoverable malady, or to test the limits of your biology. The process was a success, at least to a point, but the change left its mark on you. The indelible warping of your form can be a source of fear for those who do not understand what they see.

entries.name: Building an Experiment
entries: An experiment can come from any class or walk of life. Were you kidnapped and altered against your will, or did you volunteer for a heinous procedure? Was the experimenting done purely for discovery, to overcome a worse fate, or for someone to play at being a god? Whatever the reason, the process is never pleasant, and it always leaves scars—both those you can see and those that have marked your very soul.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Experiment Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Experiment Story Threads
rows: A particular song stirs feelings of sadness and overwhelming anger in you, reminding you of the process that changed you.
A portion of your altered body is very clearly grafted from a different person, and they might want it back.
Another person was changed alongside you. They fled before you left, urging you to do the same.
You have recurring nightmares of the procedure you endured, sometimes seeing glimpses of faces in the dream that you don't recognize.
Your physical difference invites curiosity and attention, which for some reason is more disturbing than disdain or fear.
A peculiar symbol is branded on or near your alteration.

entries.name: Experiment Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Experiment Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Experiment Trinkets
rows: A syringe with a faintly glowing purple residue
A wrench that is the only one that fits a bit of simple machinery built into your body
A sheaf of chemical-stained parchments covered in incomprehensible notes and schematics
A spool of silver thread that matches stitches in your altered body part
A metal hip flask with strange runes scratched into one side
A smooth stone that comforts and soothes you when you hold it tightly

backgroundFluff.name: Ghostlight Passenger
entries: Once, even before your most recent travel to Druskenvald, you rode the deathly train known as the {@i Ghostlight Express}. Your memories of that journey might be hazy and dreamlike, or they could be sharp and jarring in their clarity. You learned some of the workings of the ghostly engine and formed a connection with the conductor and fellow travelers that has stayed with you. At times, you are even more comfortable with the dead than the living.

entries.name: Building a Ghostlight Passenger
entries: Every person in Druskenvald travels the {@i Ghostlight Express} at least once, but very few form the deep and lasting connection that you have. Your first trip on the train might have been a near death experience from which you were saved, or perhaps you did die in earnest but were resurrected later.
Characters attuned to spirits or the lands of the dead, such as Clerics, Paladins, or those who had brushes with death, are the most common to exhibit this deep connection.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Ghostlight Passenger Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Ghostlight Passenger Story Threads
rows: Sometimes when you dream, you find yourself back on the Ghostlight Express in more than just a dream image.
Your first journey to the lands of the dead was confusing, but you realized you now may be able to find the departed spirit of a loved one once thought lost forever.
A specific spirit returns to speak to and through you repeatedly.

People sometimes speak to you as if they know you but later have no recollection of the conversation. During those moments of recognition, they know details from your visits on the Ghostlight Express.
You sometimes see people in your travels who you recognize from your time on the Ghostlight Express.
Someone greeted you with knowledge of your first journey on the Ghostlight Express, but you don't remember them.

entries.name: Ghostlight Passenger Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Ghostlight Passenger Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Ghostlight Passenger Trinkets
rows: A slate board smeared with erased chalk, where you sometimes find words scratched
A lump of coal that never burns away and gives off wispy smoke
A torn ticket stub that is slightly translucent
A dented train conductor's whistle that only the dead can hear
A pocket watch that runs backwards
A battered train conductor's hat

backgroundFluff.name: Night Stalker
entries: Once you were prey, stalked by a monster through the dark of night. Now, you are the hunter, and the things which you once feared will learn the true meaning of dread. You have become far deadlier, hungrier, and crueler than the monster that once hunted you. You are, yourself, the monster now—a fearsome creature once thought to slake its hunger on you or those close to you. You survived, and your would-be killer will have its own destruction in turn.

entries.name: Building a Night Stalker
entries: Consider how you joined the hunt against the creatures of the night. Did you lose someone close to you or survive an attack? Perhaps you were raised in a family line of dedicated hunters. Rangers, Rogues, and Barbarians make fearsome night stalkers, as does any character with a passion to oppose these deadly creatures.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Night Stalker Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Night Stalker Story Threads
rows: You're hunting the creature that slew your loved ones.
You started your hunt with zeal but quickly find that you're losing your stomach for it.
As you learn more about the creatures of the night, you discover that some of your initial thoughts about them were wrong.
You failed to stand up to a creature and saved yourself instead of someone else. Now you try to make up for that shame.
The monsters you hunt terrify you to your soul, and you lash out to deny your fear.
Your fervent hunt is a cover for your desire to become something more than mortal.

entries.name: Night Stalker Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Night Stalker Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Night Stalker Trinkets
rows: A necklace of yellowed fangs
A series of letters showing a person's personality sharply eroding into incoherence and raving
A knife made from a massive creature's claw
A casting of a monstrous footprint
A hide or pelt from a vicious beast
A glass eye that normal animals shy away from

backgroundFluff.name: Reflected Wanderer
entries: You were once whole, but part of you has been separated from your being and now also wanders the world. This aspect of you took your reflection and shadow with it, and it travels about as a mirage that looks identical to you. You know this other self is out there—you can feel it—but what it wants and why is lost on you. Sometimes you encounter a stranger that knows you—for good or ill—though you've never met them before, and you can't help but wonder if they met the other you.

entries.name: Building a Reflected Wanderer
entries: Any character can be a reflected wanderer. How was it that your being came to be divided? How much do you understand about your situation? Are you truly who you think you are, or are you, in reality, the very castoff reflection of your other self?

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Reflected Wanderer Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Reflected Wanderer Story Threads
rows: A close, long-term relationship went suddenly sour as if you wronged the other person.
Your other self leaves you messages and signs as it travels, sometimes seeming fond and other times resentful.
Animals are unsettled by you, becoming skittish and restless in your presence.
You're wanted for several minor crimes you never committed, though eyewitnesses named you. Over time, more crimes of increasing severity occur.
Someone you've been at odds with begins treating you with more respect and kindness.
Mirrors sometimes crack when you touch them.

entries.name: Reflected Wanderer Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Reflected Wanderer Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Reflected Wanderer Trinkets
rows: A shattered hand mirror
An invitation to a powerful person's home whom you've never met
A locket with your silhouette painted in it on both sides, facing each other
A short, derisive letter from yourself that you don't remember writing
A brooch delivered to you that you didn't purchase
A piece of chalk that writes in a different color than it appears to be

backgroundFluff.name: Rest Warden
entries: In a place closer to the lands of the dead than the living, those who tend the eternal rest and disposition of the deceased are held in a mixture of high esteem and apprehension. You have plied the trade of the gravedigger, the mortician, and the embalmer. There are times when you have been the only one to say a kind word in honor of those who passed. The depredations of the Undead are well-known to you, and you don't suffer their meddling in the rest of your charges.

entries.name: Building a Rest Warden
entries: Rest wardens tend to be either a dour and somber lot or—in contrast to their trade—are filled with the vibrance and joy of life. Those who understand the thin thread between life and death or who possess the strength to dig graves beneath moonlit skies and tend the bone orchards where the dead sleep are called to serve as rest wardens.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Rest Warden Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Rest Warden Story Threads
rows: A strange figure commissioned you to carve a headstone for someone who is very much in the prime of life.
In a time of desperation, you once accepted a sizeable bribe to look the other way when someone robbed a grave.
You spent time learning from Yorgrim, gravedigger and caretaker of the Maidenmist Cemetery.
Someone violated graves under your watch and stole away with the corpses.
You comforted a child at their parent's funeral and have taken a protective shine to them.
A loved one once rose from the grave as an Undead creature. You vowed to bring them to their final rest.

entries.name: Rest Warden Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Rest Warden Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Rest Warden Trinkets
rows: A prayer slip and seal covered in verses to protect the departed
A charcoal rubbing of a gravestone epitaph
A coffin nail that always ends up bent, no matter how many times you straighten it
A dried flower cleaned from one of the first graves you tended
A length of rusty iron chain and padlock
A sealed bottle containing a final breath

backgroundFluff.name: Reveler
entries: For a time, you traveled with the Lord of Fools' strange and unsettling revelry. Whether you are still welcome in that company, or you've struck off on your own, your time with the troupe revealed some of its nature to you—that the Lord of Fools serves some great entity who prizes humor and merriment, often at the expense of the mighty. But he is no mere jester. Beneath the mask of mockery and merriment is a mad creature who demands sacrifice.

entries.name: Building a Reveler
entries: The simultaneous beauty and uncomfortable truth of the revelers is that they can be anyone. Hidden by their masks and costumes, one's friends, family, servants, or lords could be capering about the ribbon-twined pole and leading impressionable folk away when the revel withdraws. How might a reveler behave differently in each guise?

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Reveler Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Reveler Story Threads
rows: Posters depicting drawings of your reveler guise have started showing up in towns after the fool's revel leaves.
Once you learned the truth of the revels—that some of the people who vanish ostensibly to join the revel are sacrificed—you seized the first chance to slip away.
Recently, more people than usual have gone missing from towns in the revel's wake.
Crows, owls, and other birds seem to cackle and laugh in your presence.
You have grown suspicious that another reveler has a sinister motive concealed by their jester's guise.
You left the revel when you caught a glimpse of the wickedness lurking beneath the Lord of Fool's jovial veneer.

entries.name: Reveler Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Reveler Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Reveler Trinkets
rows: A small wind-up bell that you can conceal in the palm of your hand with a button to activate it
A dented metal spray bottle
A string of colorful handkerchiefs tied together
A tarnished silver bell that sometimes refuses to jingle
A pair of boots or slippers that squeak comically with each step
A short scepter or baton with a horn on the cap

backgroundFluff.name: Reveler
entries: For a time, you traveled with the Lord of Fools' strange and unsettling revelry. Whether you are still welcome in that company, or you've struck off on your own, your time with the troupe revealed some of its nature to you—that the Lord of Fools serves some great entity who prizes humor and merriment, often at the expense of the mighty. But he is no mere jester. Beneath the mask of mockery and merriment is a mad creature who demands sacrifice.

entries.name: Building a Reveler
entries: The simultaneous beauty and uncomfortable truth of the revelers is that they can be anyone. Hidden by their masks and costumes, one's friends, family, servants, or lords could be capering about the ribbon-twined pole and leading impressionable folk away when the revel withdraws. How might a reveler behave differently in each guise?

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Reveler Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Reveler Story Threads
rows: Posters depicting drawings of your reveler guise have started showing up in towns after the fool's revel leaves.
Once you learned the truth of the revels—that some of the people who vanish ostensibly to join the revel are sacrificed—you seized the first chance to slip away.
Recently, more people than usual have gone missing from towns in the revel's wake.
Crows, owls, and other birds seem to cackle and laugh in your presence.
You have grown suspicious that another reveler has a sinister motive concealed by their jester's guise.
You left the revel when you caught a glimpse of the wickedness lurking beneath the Lord of Fool's jovial veneer.

entries.name: Reveler Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Reveler Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Reveler Trinkets
rows: A small wind-up bell that you can conceal in the palm of your hand with a button to activate it
A dented metal spray bottle
A string of colorful handkerchiefs tied together
A tarnished silver bell that sometimes refuses to jingle
A pair of boots or slippers that squeak comically with each step
A short scepter or baton with a horn on the cap

backgroundFluff.name: Scholar of the Forbidden
entries: Delving into the brittle pages of ancient tomes and weathered tablets carved with blasphemy, you have unearthed secrets of eldritch beings of unfathomable might. Most of their meaning slips like whispers out of your grasp, but you have seized both forbidden knowledge and cursed power from them. The deeper you plunge into depravity, the more certainty you feel that you are not there alone.

entries.name: Building a Scholar of the Forbidden
entries: Wizards and Warlocks make the most common scholars of the forbidden, but any character who stumbles onto the dread truths waiting beneath the surface of reality can find themselves walking the path. The secrets you unveil could threaten to destabilize any number of powerful beliefs and organizations, which makes you dangerous to them.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Scholar of the Forbidden Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Scholar of the Forbidden Story Threads
rows: A wealthy patron paid you handsomely to research what led to your discoveries, and they want what you found.
When you spoke aloud the first secret word you deciphered, you passed out and woke hours later to find your lips cracked and blackened.
Something has been following you since you uncovered the illicit secrets. You sense it always behind you, drawing closer.
Your shadow converses with you when you're alone, acting as a debate partner and sounding board in your studies.
The reflections of your eyes are black voids, but no one else seems to notice.
An order of inquisitors or witch hunters hound you wherever you travel, seeking to silence you and your discoveries forever.

entries.name: Scholar of the Forbidden Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Scholar of the Forbidden Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Scholar of the Forbidden Trinkets
rows: A broken fragment of a stone table carved with symbols that seem to slither and writhe
A desiccated bit of tentacle
A small soapstone idol that always seems to end up in your pocket, bag, or otherwise on your person
A book bound in Humanoid skin with blank pages that absorb ink or other pigments
An alien eyeball floating in a jar of preservative fluid
An antique amulet with indecipherable symbols, that whispers at the edge of consciousness when worn

backgroundFluff.name: Wicker Weaver
entries: You know the ancient rites kept alive by secretive druids and hedge practitioners in the shadowed groves of the primordial forests. Remedies and hexes woven into wicker charms can stave off misfortune and ward away evil. They could just as likely invite gloom and the ire of the old spirits.

entries.name: Building a Wicker Weaver
entries: Compassionate characters driven by a deep connection to the land and a passion to protect it become wicker weavers. Druids of other circles might trade knowledge with the Circle of Wicker. Healers and guardians alike may seek out the Old Ways for remedies and protective charms to ward off evil. Not all who come to the wicker craft do so with noble intent—some, broken by spite and twisted by their pain, wield the power of the wicker into malicious revenge, lashing out with curses bound in twig and bone and inflicting the wrath of the forest upon those who wronged them.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Wicker Weaver Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Wicker Weaver Story Threads
rows: One of the charms you created ensured a baby was born healthy, and their family sends you small but heartfelt gifts.
Your mentor who taught you the craft has become increasingly withdrawn and uncharacteristically agitated.
An order of druids, the Circle of Wicker, taught you their ways. You aren't certain why.
Someone offered you a shocking sum of coin to twist a wicker charm for them. You're tempted but unsettled by the unwarranted generosity.
You traded a wicker charm for a child's toy that bound misfortune to its owner. You must keep it until you can sell it, it's stolen, or you lose it.
You wove a hex into a wicker charm to punish a criminal, and they nurse that grudge still.

entries.name: Wicker Weaver Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Wicker Weaver Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Wicker Weaver Trinkets
rows: A crescent woven from wicker and laced with silver wire
A glass bauble that was the first payment you received for your hedge wisdom
A Tiny figure made of acorn caps from the oldest oak in the woods
A rough-forged knife with an etched blade
A snake skull in a wicker cage
A battered stuffed animal missing one eye

subclassFeatures: Warrior of the Pestilent Haze|Monk|XPHB|Pestilent Haze|CrookedMoon24|3

subclassFeatures: Circle of the Old Ways|Druid|XPHB|Old Ways|CrookedMoon24|3

subclass.name: Way of the Pestilent Haze
subclassFeatures: Way of the Pestilent Haze|Monk|PHB|Pestilent Haze|CrookedMoon14|3

subclassFeature.name: Great Fool Patron
entries: {@i Laugh in the Face of Danger with Foolish Antics}

What horrors and sorrows can't be remedied by maniacal laughter? Warlocks that have made a pact with the Great Fool draw their enigmatic power from a powerful, otherworldly being of jolly revelry, whose twisted sense of humor is lost on mortal understanding. They are a mocking mirror to bring low the arrogant and mighty, though the Great Fool's ultimate designs are often nonsensical and incomprehensible.

Many Warlocks of the Great Fool adopt a signature aesthetic and performance style that best represents their folly. The Foolish Personas table offers archetypes of fools with suggestions for corresponding outfits and routines.

entries.caption: Foolish Personas
rows: {@b The Harlequin.} An elegant outfit of diamond motley with a painted mask—performs dances, gives eloquent speeches, and plays tricks
{@b The Jester.} A two-toned, checkered motley outfit with cap and bells—favors feats of acrobatics, tumbling, and juggling
{@b The Joker.} A vibrant, colorful suit with wild hair and bowler hat—favors silly jokes, slapstick comedy, and clumsy self-deprecation
{@b The Mime.} A striped, black-and-white shirt with a flat cap and red suspenders—pantomimes comical scenarios without speaking
{@b The Sad Clown.} A monochromatic, one-piece outfit with pointed hat and puffball buttons—utilizes melodramatic melancholy and song
{@b The Tramp.} A patch-covered coat, tattered scarf, scuffed shoes, and cigar—leverages sardonic wit, insults, and mocking observations

subclassFeature.name: Great Fool Spells
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Great Fool Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Great Fool Spells
rows: {@spell Disguise Self|XPHB}, {@spell Tasha's Hideous Laughter|XPHB}, {@spell Rope Trick|XPHB}, {@spell Spiritual Weapon|XPHB}, {@spell Vicious Mockery|XPHB}
{@spell Blink|XPHB}, {@spell Stinking Cloud|XPHB}
{@spell Phantasmal Killer|XPHB}, {@spell Puppet Master|CrookedMoon24}
{@spell Bigby's Hand|XPHB}, {@spell Mislead|XPHB}

subclassFeature.name: Killing Joke
entries: You see the humor in everything—especially in the end of things. When a creature you can see within 60 feet of you takes damage or fails a saving throw, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to cast {@spell Vicious Mockery|XPHB} on that creature. You can use this {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain one expended use when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Jester's Japes
entries: By calling down an aspect of the Great Fool, you can curse your foes. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you target a creature you can see within 60 feet of you and force it to succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or suffer one of the following curses (your choice).

entries.name: Flower Spurt
entries: You spray a strange liquid at the creature's eyes, giving it the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Clown Shoes
entries: The creature's feet or similar appendages grow to awkwardly exaggerated proportions. The creature's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is halved, and it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on ability checks and saving throws that rely on Dexterity.

entries.name: Honk Honk
entries: The creature emits sounds, such as honks, chimes, or squeaks, that are audible out to 100 feet with every movement, no matter how slight. The creature can't benefit from the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Jolly Arms
entries: Any weapon or {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} the creature attacks with, including natural weapons such as fangs and claws, takes on a comical appearance as if it were made of wood, stuffed cloth, or balloons. The target deals half damage with weapon attacks and {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes}.
The curse lasts for 1 minute. The creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the curse on a success.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Mocking Banter
entries: Your witty and insulting japes become biting to the point of needling your foes' very psyche. When a creature damages you, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to force the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature takes Psychic damage equal to the triggering damage you took, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Once you use this {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Send in the Clowns
entries: You can call upon the laughing, jeering spirits of the followers of the Great Fool to strike down your foes. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you summon three ghostly fools. The fools are translucent and intangible, and they resemble clowns, jesters, or similar entertainers. Make up to three melee spell attacks against creatures within 60 feet of you. On a hit, a target takes {@damage 2d10} Psychic damage and has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn, or the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition (your choice). You can use your action on subsequent turns to repeat the attacks.

The fools remain for 1 minute or until you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition or you die. Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: The Horned King
entries: {@i Live Deliciously with Bewitching Power}

Whether motivated by desperation or cunning, warlocks that have signed their name in the book of the Horned King have chosen to live deliciously in a pact sealed in blood and a corrupted soul. Bestowed the power of witchcraft by the beast that stalks the deepest woods and darkest hearts, they perfect ancient rituals and weave maledictions toward aims only they know. With each victim of their malign spells filled with rot, hate, and agony, they become more like their patron until they effortlessly wield his kingly might.
Warlocks of the Horned King prefer particular implements in working their magic. The Witchcraft Implements table offers options for your favored reagents.

entries.caption: Witchcraft Implements
rows: Candles made from tallow mixed with blood
Dried bundles of herbs or mushrooms
Skulls or long bones carved with glyphs
Crushed berries or roots mixed into a paste
Iron cauldron marked with symbols
Curved blade for offering animal sacrifices

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Horned King Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Horned King Expanded Spells
rows: {@spell Animal Friendship|PHB}, {@spell Bane|PHB}, {@spell Spike Growth|PHB}, {@spell Suggestion|PHB}
{@spell Bestow Curse|PHB}, {@spell Fly|PHB}
{@spell Phantasmal Killer|PHB}, {@spell Polymorph|PHB}
{@spell Dominate Person|PHB}, {@spell Scrying|PHB}

subclassFeature.name: Witch Mark
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can imbue magic into a nonmagical Tiny object you're holding. Choose one warlock spell you know that has a casting time of 1 action. A creature holding the marked object can take an action to cast the spell (using your Charisma modifier, spell attack bonus, or spell save DC). The mark fades when the spell is cast from it or when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Malediction
entries: You can call upon the Horned King's malice to manipulate luck and fate. As an action, you can magically curse a creature you can see within 60 feet of you until the end of its next turn. Alternatively, when a creature within range targets you with an attack roll or a spell, you can use your reaction to curse the creature with your choice of one of the curses below. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Agony
entries: The target has disadvantage on its next attack roll or Constitution saving throw to maintain {@status concentration|PHB} (your choice).

entries.name: Hate
entries: The target has disadvantage on its next Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw (your choice).

entries.name: Rot
entries: The next time the target takes damage, it takes an extra {@damage 1d10} necrotic damage, and it can't regain hit points until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Spiteful Curse
entries: When you use {@subclassFeature Malediction|Warlock|PHB|Horned King|CrookedMoon14|1|CrookedMoon14}, you can now cast {@spell Bestow Curse|PHB} once without a spell slot as the action or reaction for that feature, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a long rest. If the target succeeds on its saving throw against the spell, your use of this feature isn't expended.

When you cast the spell in this way, its range becomes 60 feet, and it lasts 1 minute with no {@status concentration|PHB} required. If the target succeeds on its saving throw against the spell, choose one of the {@subclassFeature Malediction|Warlock|PHB|Horned King|CrookedMoon14|1|CrookedMoon14} curses, and the target suffers that curse instead.

subclassFeature.name: Crown of Horns
entries: As a bonus action, you can manifest the majestic might of the Horned King for 1 minute. For the duration, a visible mark appears on you—such as a crown made of horns surmounting your head, or you grow great antlers—and you gain the benefits listed below. Once you use this bonus action, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest unless you expend a warlock spell slot (no action required) to restore your use of it.

entries.name: Dark Heart
entries: Once on each of your turns when you damage a creature, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d8} necrotic damage.

entries.name: King of All
entries: You radiate an aura of power out to 20 feet from you. When you activate this feature, and at the start of each of your turns, you can choose a creature you can see in the aura. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or suffer one of the following effects of your choice until the start of your next turn:

items.name: Enticement
entries: The target is {@condition charmed|PHB} by you.

items.name: Wickedness
entries: The target has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

items.name: Terror
entries: The target is {@condition frightened|PHB} of you and must move away from you by the safest route during its turn unless there is nowhere to move.

subclassFeature.name: Gather the Coven
entries: You can now share the Horned King's power with those you deem worthy. You perform a 1-hour ritual, which can be done during a rest, forming a bond with up to six willing creatures that must remain within 10 feet of you during the ritual. You can end the bond for any number of the creatures (no action required), and the bond ends when you die. The bond grants the following benefits.

entries.name: Witchcraft
entries: Choose one of the curses from your {@subclassFeature Malediction|Warlock|PHB|Horned King|CrookedMoon14|1|CrookedMoon14} feature. The bonded creatures can now each use that reaction option once, and they regain the ability to do so when they finish a long rest.

entries.name: Fly By Night
entries: As a bonus action, choose one of the bonded creatures. If you and the target are on the same plane of existence, you magically teleport to the nearest unoccupied space next to the creature. You can use this benefit once, and you regain the ability to do so when you finish a short or long rest. If your Crown of Horns feature is active when you use this bonus action, the use isn't expended.

entries.name: Hand of the King
entries: While your Crown of Horns feature is active, the first time a bonded creature damages another creature during its turn, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d10} necrotic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Horned King Patron

entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can manifest the majestic might of the Horned King for 1 minute. entries.name: King of All
entries: You radiate an aura of power in a 20-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} that originates from you. When you activate this feature, and at the start of each of your turns, you can choose a creature you can see in the aura. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or suffer one of the following effects of your choice until the start of your next turn:

items.name: Enticement

items.name: Wickedness
